div.p: A number stored with arbitrary precision. Numbers in the NetLogo environment are represented as IEEE double-precision floating point numbers. These numbers work great for the ranges used in NetLogo, but are sometimes insufficiently expressive when dealing with very large or very small numbers. In those cases, we use big decimal types to indicate that the number can have arbitrary precision. These numbers are formatted the same way as doubles.
A double color is a number stored to represent a NetLogo color. See the Colors section of the programming guide for more information.
Booleans represent a true / false value.
Characters represent a single letter by using a length-one string.
A list of strings, separated by a comma (',') and a single space (' '). These lists denote a collection of strings.
A IEEE double-precision floating point numbers stored as an element or attribute

A sequence of floating-point values separated by a comma (','). This is designed to mirror SVG's dasharray data type. At the moment, there are only five combinations supported by NetLogo. Hex Color represents a color using the '#' followed by 6 hex-digits. The first two digits represent the red component of the color, the second two green, and the final two blue. For more information, see the Hex Triplet at Wikipedia.

Please note that while HTML/CSS allow using other color selectors (like three digit hex abbreviations, color names, or css colors created with rgb), this type only permits the use of full hex triples.
Represents an integer value that may be positive, negative, or zero.

An approximation of the SVG list-of-points type. This type contains a sequence of pairs with first and second components of the pair separated by a comma (',') and each pair separated from the next pair by a space (' ').
Represents an integer value greater than or equal to zero.
Represents an integer value greater than zero.

Represents a string value. Because nlogox is an XML-based format, strings must be properly-formatted for XML. In practice, NetLogo saves all string-typed values contained in elements using CDATA. We recommend that any file modification do the same, both for ease of implementation and to preserve whitespace in regions that frequently represent code. For string-typed values in attributes, ensure that the string is HTML-safe by escaping characters as appropriate.
